The application is made pursuant to Section 96A of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended), which concerns non-material amendments to planning permission. Under Section 96A, a change may be made to any planning permission, including through the imposition of new conditions or the removal/alteration of existing conditions, if the local planning authority is satisfied that the change is not material. In deciding whether a change is material, a local planning authority must have regard to the effect of the change, together with any previous changes made under this section, on the planning permission as originally granted. The National Planning Practice Guidance states that there is no statutory definition of 'non-material'. This is because it will be dependent on the context of the overall scheme - an amendment that is non-material in one context may be material in another. The judgement on 'materially' in any particular case is one of fact and degree.The applicant seeks a non material amendment to planning permission ref. no 21/00809/HOU to allow an increase the area of the single storey rear/side extensionOfficers considered the amendments to be material and would require an additional assessment on the character, appearance and amenity of the proposal and would therefore require a S73 application to amend the original permission.

IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2022.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Consultations4 no surrounding properties were notified  of the proposed development. No  letters of representation were received.  Proposal The application seeks full planning permission for the erection of a single storey rear/side extension.Application SiteThe  site comprises a semi detached dwelling. The application site is within a  Grove Lane Local Area of Special Character and within Flood Zone 2 & 3.Planning Assessment  The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Impact on Heritage Assets- Flood Risk- Fire Safety DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale , appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer comment : The proposal seeks the erection of a single storey rear/ side extension. The existing dwelling presents a part two storey/ part single storey outrigger which measures a depth of 6.545m from the rear elevation of the original dwelling and a width of 2.447m. The existing storey element  presents a single aspect pitch tiled roof with a parapet height of 3.658m and eaves height of 2.362m. It is proposed that the proposed roof would be a green roof and accommodate 3 roof lights. The proposed single storey rear and side extension would project a maximum depth of 7.7m  and a width of 4.699m. It would  exceed the width of the original dwelling and be positioned hard against the shared boundary with no 77 Portland Road. It would present a flat roof eaves height of 3m The parapet feature between no73 and No75 Portland Road would remain in place.The proposed side elevation  of the extension facing towards no 77  would present a flank wall  and the rear elevation would present aluminium sliding doors.  The proposed extension itself would be constructed from London Stock brickwork. Within the context of the existing built form on site and the siting of the single storey side and rear extension, it is considered that the proposal would appear as a proportionate and subordinate addition to the main dwellinghouse and that it would be acceptable from a character and design perspective.Overall, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The principal property  to consider in relation to amenity  is the immediate neighbouring property at no 77 Portland Road. The proposed side elevation of the extension would present a flank wall. Even though the separation distance between the neighbouring properties would be reduced, adequate separation distance remains in situ.   Officer Comment:  Given the proportionate and subordinate nature  of the proposed development and its siting in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Impact on Heritage AssetsParagraphs 195 to 208 of the NPPF (December 2023) set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.Officer comment:  The application site falls within  Grove Lane  Local Area of Special Character,  a non designated heritage asset.  Within the context of the existing built form and noting the  assessment above,  it is considered that the proposal would  not have an adverse impact on the character and appearance of the area and would harm the significance of the   Grove Lane Local Area of Special Character. Flood RiskPolicy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM4 of the Council's Core strategy 2012 require development proposals to accord with the flood risk policies set out in the NPPF.Officer Comment: The application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2/3. Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts. Fire safety London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy.  Officers are satisfied that the proposal adequately meets the requirements of Policy D12(A). Ongoing compliance with the strategy would be secured through conditions, in the event of a favourable recommendation. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.Building RegulationsYour attention is drawn to the need to comply with the relevant provisions of the Building Regulations, the Building Acts and other related legislation.  These cover such works as  - the demolition of existing buildings, the erection of a new building or structure, the extension or alteration to a building, change of use of buildings, installation of services, underpinning works, and fire safety/means of escape works.  Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts.  A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.Party Wall ActThe Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from, any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to:- carry out work to an existing party wall;- build on the boundary with a neighbouring property;- in some circumstances, carry out groundworks within 6 metres of an adjoining building.Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".Property BoundariesYour attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights, and that if your proposal involves construction on or near the site boundary then you should take appropriate steps to ensure that you have correctly identified the position of the boundary, that you do not build over it, and that any works which affect a neighbours property in any way have the benefit of the appropriate agreement from that landowner. Failure to undertake the above steps may leave you liable to legal action by neighbouring landowners. If you require further information or advice, you should consult a solicitor.Consistency of PlansReasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans submitted for the purposes of this planning application are consistent from one to the next, and that the development hereby approved can be implemented in accordance with all of the plans submitted. Should it transpire that this is not possible and that your plans are flawed, please be clear that it may be impossible to implement this permission, and that any development undertaken which relies on this permission may be unauthorised and subject to enforcement action if expedient.Construction Site NoiseWhen undertaking demolition and/or noisy building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays.  You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation, and that any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Council's Environmental Health Department.Definition of Approved in WritingWhere reference is made within the decision notice to a condition applying 'unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority', please be aware that only a formal application under section 73 or 96a of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (As Amended) is acceptable as a method of said written agreement.Ground Level / Base LevelUnless clearly specified otherwise, the base of the development shown on the approved plans is taken to be external ground level, and not a Damp Proof Course or Internal Finished Floor Level. The external ground level is expected to remain consistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a semi detached dwelling The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Proposal Addition to the existing extension to make total rear extension of 5.5m from the rear wall of the original property  and a maximum total height of 3.00m from NSLConsultations3 properties were notified of the proposal. One representation has been received with comments summarised as follows:- Excessive height or bulk of buildings- Loss of light/Sunlight- Increased sense of enclosure The above concerns will be addressed within this assessment. The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The application site benefits from a staggered rear extension that is approximately 2.8m deep along the common boundary with No 70.The proposed single storey, full width rear extension would be of a total depth of approximately 5.55m and total height of approximately 3m. The proposed separation distance to the common boundary with No 70 would be similar to the existing, approximately 10cm. It is acknowledged that the proposed single storey rear extension would not be strictly in accordance with Policy Guidance 33 of the Council's Residential Design SPD with regards to the recommended depth up to 3.5m for semi detached properties. However, it is noted that the proposed depth is not uncharacteristic to the area. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Officers note objections raised within the written representations that the proposal may significantly reduce the level of daylight received by the adjoining property, appear as an overbearing and increase sense of enclosure. Given the proposed height of the extension and its siting, it would pass the 45 degree rule in elevation view and therefore it would not result in an unacceptable loss of daylight in relation to the closest habitable, ground floor window at No 70. However as the proposal would be set along the boundary with No 70, which shows its original, staggered layout, it is considered that the proposal due to its excessive scale and siting it would appear as an overbearing and it would create a sense of enclosure in relation to the nearest, principle window at the ground floor level at this adjoining property. It is noted that properties benefit from relatively narrow gardens and no mature vegetation along the boundaries to mitigate any impacts. Given the above, it is considered that the proposed rear extension, by reason of its depth and siting, would appear as an overbearing when viewed from No 70 Grand Avenue and it would increase a sense of enclosure, resulting in unacceptable living conditions for occupants at No 70. As such, the proposal is therefore contrary to policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling within the Tudor Estate Local Area of Special Character.ProposalErection of two storey side and part two storey/part single storey rear extension. Erection of single storey front porch and first floor front bay window extension.It is noted that the same proposal was submitted and approved under application 07/12660/FUL dated 11/07/2007 but was not built out at the time so has been resubmitted now. Consultation14 neighbouring properties have been notified and one objection has been received stating; - Access or traffic problems - PrivacyAssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development and the impact on the Tudor Estate Local Area of Special Character; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire safety. DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Paragraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.The Tudor Estate Local Area of Special Character is a non-designated heritage asset.Paragraph 203 of the NPPF states that:The effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining the application. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement will be required having regard to the scale of any harm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset.Officer Comment: Officers note that no harm was identifed when the previous application was approved and Officers conclude that the current application would have the same impact. The proposed development is therefore considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. To ensure consistancy the same conditions applied with the previos permission will also apply with this permission.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: As noted above, no harm has been identified subject to the same conditions being applied.  It is therefore considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the lack of detail supplied is insufficent. However, officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

The site comprises a detached dwelling.13 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development.- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Fire Safety.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: Officers acknowledge that in principle a proposed piggyback extension would not be an incongruous addition to the street scene as several dwellings benefit from a similar extension. However, the submitted drawings demonstrate that the piggyback extension would not align with Policy Guidance 40, of the Residential Design SPD. The extension would not maintain 4m or more from the front elevation of the dwelling and it would increase the ridge height by approximately 1.5m, instead of 1.3m, stated in Policy Guidance 40. Therefore, the proposed development would appear overly prominent in the streetscene. Overall, the proposed development is considered to be unacceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be an adverse impact on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Officers have assessed the impact on daylighting and sunlighting of the proposed rear extension, using the BRE, 45 and 25 Degree Rule and the Residential Design SPD to ensure minimum impact on neighbouring amenities.Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Report which suitably addresses the provisions of Policy D12(A). For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would not be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2023), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a detached dwelling. The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Proposal Demolition of existing single storey rear extension and erection of part single/part two storey rear extension. Conversion of garage to habitable room and associated changes to fenestrations.Consultations6 properties were notified of the proposal.  One neutral representation has been received with regards to the project's potential for biodiversity enhancement - swift boxes.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: It is acknowledged that the proposed 6m single storey rear extension would not be strictly in accordance with Policy Guidance 33 of the Council's Residential Design SPD with regards to the recommended depth. However, Officers note the successful application 23/02814/PAEXT for an approximately 6m  deep extension, which is considered a 'fallback' position in this case. The proposed first floor rear extension, due to its width, the proposed design and its siting is considered to be in-keeping with the host dwelling.The proposed alterations to the front elevation and conversion of the garage into habitable room are considered to be acceptable and in-keeping with the host dwelling and the surrounding area. Given the above, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development due to its siting and scale would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.The proposal due to its siting and scale would pass the 45 degree rule and therefore it would not result in an unacceptable loss of daylight in relation to the adjoining properties. Loss of Car ParkingParagraph 115 of the NPPF, 2023 states that development should only be prevented or refused on transport grounds if there would be an unacceptable impact on highway safety, or where the residual cumulative impacts of development are severe. Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 requires development proposals to have regard to local traffic conditions and highway safety and ensure they are not adversely affected. Officer Comment: Despite the loss of the existing garage, it is considered that the hardstanding to the front of the dwelling remains of an adequate size to accommodate one off street car parking space, therefore the proposal would not result in an unacceptable impact on the local highway network. Officers note no parking restrictions on South Lane. In relation to cycle parking, Officers note that a secure cycle parking could be possibly provided within the existing amenity space to compensate for the loss of the garage. Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Statement, which is considered to be acceptable.BiodiversityWhile Officers note that the proposed development due to its scale has been exempt from biodiversity gain requirements, as per received comments, the application site is situated within an area when swifts (classified as endangered species) occur. Therefore, a relevant condition would be added for installation of swift bricks or swift boxes at roof level, to promote swift conservation in their area.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe application site comprises a detached family dwelling, pool house and an outbuilding. The site falls within the Coombe Hill Conservation Area and Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character and is covered by a group Tree Preservation Order.Proposal Erection of roof extension with side dormer, reduction in roof height, associated changes to fenestrations and restoration of roof apex. (Retrospective)ConsultationsConservation Areas Advisory Committee - objections to the proposed uPVC windows Representations12 properties were notified of the proposal. Two representations have been received with comments summarised as follows:- Excessive height or bulk of buildings - Inappropriate design/layout - PrivacyThe above concerns will be addressed within the report. The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- The impact of the development on the Heritage Assets; and,- The impact of the development on the protected trees; and,- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed alterations to the existing front roof dormer comprising reduction of its height, restoration of the original roof ridge and roof eaves, minimising the width of the top white PVC fascia and replacement of the windows (to be similar in style to the existing windows) are considered acceptable and in-keepin of the host building and the surrounding area. Officers note concerns raised within the written representation about the unacceptable  appearance and poor quality of the design. However, it is considered that the proposed alterations that would reduce the overall bulk of the dormer, minimise the appearance of white PVC fascia and improve the style and quality of proposed windows would result in a proportionate and more adequate addition to the host building. The proposal would not be visible with Coombe Lane West, therefore there would be no significant impact on the existing street scene. It should be noted that the proposed outbuilding must remain ancillary to the host dwelling and cannot be used as a separate unit of accommodation. Any change of use would require a separate planning application. Heritage AssetsSection 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.                                                                                                                  In determining planning applications which affect heritage assets, Paragraph  203 of the NPPF 2023 requires local planning authorities to take account of: the desirability of sustaining and enhancing the significance of heritage assets and putting them to viable uses consistent with their conservation; the positive contribution that conservation of heritage assets can make to sustainable communities including their economic vitality; and the desirability of new development making a positive contribution to local character and distinctiveness.                                                                                                                     Paragraph 205 of NPPF 2023 states that when considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the assets conservation, irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance.                                              Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Core Strategy 2012 sets out the Council's commitment to preserve or enhance the existing heritage assets of the Borough through the promotion of high quality design and a focus on heritage-led regeneration. The Council will allow alterations which preserve or enhance the established character and architectural interest of a heritage asset, its fabric or its setting, and will ensure that development proposals affecting historic assets will use high quality materials and design features which incorporate or compliment those of the host building or the immediate area. Features of local importance and special interest will be respected through the consideration of form, scale, layout and detailed designs of a site, area or streetscape.Paragraphs 200 to 204 of the NPPF 2023 set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.Officer comment: The application site falls within  Coombe Hill Conservation Area and Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character. The special architectural and historic interest of this area can be summarised as The estate and hinterland to the demolished Coombe Warren, containing several mid 19th century properties by architect George Devey and other large interesting 20th century houses in a spacious landscaped setting, adjoining Coombe Hill Golf Course.The application property is not listed or locally listed and is considered to be a neutral feature.As the proposal would not be visible from the public vantage points and due to its modest scale, the proposed design and materials, it is considered that it would be in-keeping with the host dwelling and the surrounding, therefore the proposed development would be appropriate for the property located within a conservation area. Officers note objections received from a Conservation Area Advisory Committee regarding the proposed windows, however considering that the proposed type, design and material would be of similar appearance to the existing windows, it is considered that this element of the proposal would not result in any harm to the host building and the conservation area. Having regard to the above, officers conclude that the proposal would not result in any harm to the Coombe Hill Conservation Area or to Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character and would preserve its significance. It is therefore not necessary to weigh the proposed development against any public benefits.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Concerns have been raised that the proposed windows would overlook the habitable windows at the adjoining property. The separation distance between the proposed dormer and the rear elevation at No 152 would be approximately 25.50m, in line with Policy Guidance 31 of the Council's Residential Design SPD, that recommends the distances no less than 21m. However, during the site visit the Officer noted that windows would directly face the habitable windows at the first floor in rear elevation at No 152. Therefore a relevant condition would be added for the proposed windows to be obscure glazed and non-openable below 1.7m from the internal floor level. Due to the separation distance and the proposed design, it is considered that the proposal would not appear as an overbearing when viewed from the adjoining properties. Given its siting it would not impact the levels of dayligh recived by the adjoing properties. Protected TreesPolicy G7 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should ensure that, wherever possible, existing trees of value are retained. If planning permission is granted that necessitates the removal of trees, there should be adequate replacement. Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 expects new development to ensure that trees that are important to the character of the area or covered by Tree Preservation Orders (TPOs) are not adversely affected.The applicant submitted an Arbicortual Report to demonstrate no adverse impact on the protected trees. Given that the proposal is limited to the roofline only, it is considered that there would be no significant impact on the existing trees as a result of the proposal. Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has submitted a Fire Strategy Statement, which is considered to be acceptable.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be  in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

--- Officer Report ---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2022.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Application SiteThe site comprises a residential dwelling.ConsultationOne objection received. The objection is summarised as follows - Loss of light/SunlightRelevant history 23/01494/HOU - Erection of single storey rear, front, first floor side and front porch extension. Roof extension with rear dormer and installation of 3 nos front roof lights. Refused Appeal DismissedProposal The application is a revision of planning application 23/01494/HOU.  The differences are - removal of side dormer - reduction in depth of single storey rear extension by 500mm along shared side boundary on side of No.57- reduction in height of single storey rear extension by 500mm along shared side boundary on side of No.57AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS) (2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The application is a revision of planning application 23/01494/HOU. The proposal does not follow the guiding principles of the Council's Residential Design SPD. The scheme has been revised to remove the side dormer and reduce the depth and height of the single storey rear extension on the side boundary. This is in response to the Inspector raising these concerns in upholding the LPA's decision. It is considered on balance given the range of different extensions of scale and design in the surrounding area, the revisions made to the scheme and the Inspectors commentary in their decision in regards to planning application 23/01494/HOU it is in this instance considered that the proposed development would be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design and that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  The proposal is a revision of planning application 23/01494/HOU. The revisions reduce the depth and height of the single storey rear extension.  It is considered that the proposed development on balance given the reduction in height and depth of the extension by 500mm along shared side boundary on side of No.57 would not result in a loss of daylight/sunlight or outlook that would cause demonstrable harm to the existing living conditions of the existing neighbouring occupiers. It is considered that the proposal would not result in an increase of overlooking of the neighbouring properties or result in a loss of privacy to neighbouring occupiers. Overall on balance it is considered tha tthe proposal would not cause demonstrable harm to the residential amenities of neighbouring occupiersOther matters A condition is recommended to require the submission of a fire safety strategy to ensure the proposed development would comply with policy D12 of the London Plan. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to not be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than not in accordance with the development plan.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.Building RegulationsYour attention is drawn to the need to comply with the relevant provisions of the Building Regulations, the Building Acts and other related legislation.  These cover such works as  - the demolition of existing buildings, the erection of a new building or structure, the extension or alteration to a building, change of use of buildings, installation of services, underpinning works, and fire safety/means of escape works.  Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts.  A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.Party Wall ActThe Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from, any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to:- carry out work to an existing party wall;- build on the boundary with a neighbouring property;- in some circumstances, carry out groundworks within 6 metres of an adjoining building.Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".Property BoundariesYour attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights, and that if your proposal involves construction on or near the site boundary then you should take appropriate steps to ensure that you have correctly identified the position of the boundary, that you do not build over it, and that any works which affect a neighbours property in any way have the benefit of the appropriate agreement from that landowner. Failure to undertake the above steps may leave you liable to legal action by neighbouring landowners. If you require further information or advice, you should consult a solicitor.Consistency of PlansReasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans submitted for the purposes of this planning application are consistent from one to the next, and that the development hereby approved can be implemented in accordance with all of the plans submitted. Should it transpire that this is not possible and that your plans are flawed, please be clear that it may be impossible to implement this permission, and that any development undertaken which relies on this permission may be unauthorised and subject to enforcement action if expedient.Construction Site NoiseWhen undertaking demolition and/or noisy building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays.  You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation, and that any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Council's Environmental Health Department.Definition of Approved in WritingWhere reference is made within the decision notice to a condition applying 'unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority', please be aware that only a formal application under section 73 or 96a of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (As Amended) is acceptable as a method of said written agreement.Ground Level / Base LevelUnless clearly specified otherwise, the base of the development shown on the approved plans is taken to be external ground level, and not a Damp Proof Course or Internal Finished Floor Level. The external ground level is expected to remain consistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.
